title: Woman pours water on homeless man after watching him being attacked
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

A shocking video shows a homeless man being punched and kicked, before a woman throws a bottle of liquid over him.

The man had been walking through Brighton on Sunday October 13, when a group of people ‘piled’ on him in the street.

A passerby then filmed them seemingly kicking him on the floor while he groaned in pain.

In the footage, a woman can be heard shouting at the gang: ‘Stop! Stop! What are you doing?’ while a male voice threatens: ‘I will knock you out.’

The camera then pans to a man wearing a black puffer jacket standing over the victim while angrily pointing his finger in his face.

They were heard shouting threats at the man (Picture: Sussex News and Pictures)

A woman in a black hoodie then throws a liquid over the homeless man, while another tells the person filming to ‘stay out of it’.

The group then turns and walks away leaving the victim yelling out on the ground.

A witness told The Argus: ‘I was on my way to the cinema when it happened. It was awful, they were following him along the road shouting at him and then they all piled on him.

‘People were screaming “stop, stop” but they kept going. He wasn’t even fighting back. They kept shouting at him while he was on the floor.

‘It’s terrible to see this happening on our city’s streets, I really hope the poor man is OK.’

One woman threw a bottle of liquid over the man before the group left (Picture: Sussex News and Pictures)

A spokesperson for Sussex Police confirmed they had launched an investigation.

They said: ‘At 8.35pm on Sunday a 60-year-old man was attacked by a number of people in Duke Street, Brighton, sustaining injuries from kicking and punching.

‘Video taken at the time was given to police by a passerby and enquiries are ongoing.’

Anyone with information about the attack should contact the police online at sussex.police.uk/contact/af/contact-us/ or by calling 101.
